stream_context.summary: Kaze focuses on revising and bug-fixing the Goomba boss fight based on Biobak’s feedback, including spiky Goombas, boulder/goomba AI behavior, animations, boss doors, and despawn/draw-distance behavior. He also shows recent N64-accuracy fixes (mipmaps, lighting bug/crash fixes) and experiments with a bloom-like post effect, while discussing YouTube audience expectations and upcoming video/title strategy to clarify that he’s building a new game on SM64 decomp.
stream_context.significance_reason: Contains concrete boss-fight redesign decisions driven by team feedback, multiple N64 technical fixes/experiments (mipmaps, lighting, bloom), and clear statements about project communication strategy (explaining to the wider audience that this is a new game, not “more SM64 videos”).

findings.summary: Biobak requested changes to the Goomba boss fight, and Kaze adopts them, framing the day’s mission as “fixing the Goombas fight” and implementing the revised behavior.

The intended boss-fight loop is clarified: the Goomba King selects a location and walks there; the boulder’s targeting follows Mario (not the boss), so the player must position/aim so the boulder hits the boss.

A visible “teleport/disappear” glitch with the spiky Goombas is traced to a face-angle pitch value going unstable at a certain moment; Kaze adjusts logic around face angle pitch to stabilize the behavior.
Kaze identifies a randomness bug in boss positioning: numbers were generated in the range 0..1 when he expected -1..1, causing biased/incorrect position generation; he fixes this and tunes distances.

Boulder behavior required multiple fixes: it rolled too far, directions were inverted at one point, and Goombas were not reliably approaching/pushing it; Kaze tunes movement amounts and approach logic so one or both Goombas can push it and the boulder can be “shot” toward the target.

Kaze plans additional boss-fight polish: dirt impact effect when the Goomba hits the ground, making the Goomba King less likely to stand in the arena center during certain phases to reduce accidental hits, and improving how the boss “disappears” so it looks natural instead of popping/moving out abruptly.

Zeina is assigned remaining animation needs for the Goomba King (notably a kick animation and an “angry” animation idea); Kaze explicitly plans to message Zeina with the animation list and send her the newest file.

Kaze uses Blender via Fast64 for export; he notes Fast64 produces an “animation table” arrangement he didn’t expect, and he debugs animation-index issues (e.g., a specific animation slot causing a crash and missing a walk-forward export).

Kaze implemented mipmaps and highlights them as an N64-facing improvement; he also says he fixed several N64 bugs in the last two days, including lighting working correctly again after a macro-related bug, plus a crash fix in the Goomba area.

He experiments with a bloom-like effect and evaluates feasibility in N64 terms; he references an example effect costing ~7 ms of RDP time and suggests bloom might be usable only in small/sub-areas that are close to performance-perfect (e.g., a casino/space-arcade-themed area).

He adjusts boss despawn/draw-distance thresholds: current disappearance around 2000 units feels too early; he wants ~2500–2600. He also tweaks geometry/collision to prevent Goombas getting stuck on stairs/fences and to stop spike Goombas from jumping over a fence.

Kaze considers collision-map simplification: removing unnecessary triangles/sections (even if the benefit is small) to save RAM bytes and slightly improve FPS, and because extra collision can interfere with enemy movement.
On UI redesign, Kaze rejects arbitrary “3D world UI” ideas and states the UI must feel like a natural evolution of Mario 64’s existing UI rather than a disconnected redesign.

Kaze discusses channel/video strategy: upcoming BLJ video (uncertain performance), then a video explicitly explaining he’s rewriting SM64 to build his own game (and why progress previews aren’t on the main channel), and later a Missing Link update video that he plans to pay “Zell” to produce.

Kaze frames long-haul game development as requiring unusual persistence: to finish difficult, unrewarding tasks and push through compromises/creative block, he argues you need an extreme mindset and discipline rather than relying on fun/motivation.
findings.quote: If you want to be successful making video games you need to be mentally unwell.

biobak.summary: Biobak proposes changes to the Goomba boss fight that Kaze implements (core loop: boss picks a spot; boulder follows Mario; player aims boulder into boss).
Biobak supplies/owns the Goomba King model used in the fight (Kaze refers to it as “the Goomba King model from Biobak”).

Biobak suggests stronger YouTube video titles to explain the project to a wider audience; Kaze credits him with “great ideas,” notably “The secret reason I’ve been rewriting Mario 64,” which Kaze believes could dramatically increase views.
biobak.quote: Biobak had great ideas… The secret reason I’ve been rewriting Mario 64.

biobak.summary: Biobak is asked for (and apparently maintains) door/shadow assets/files for the boss doors; Kaze temporarily loses track of the file, worries about WeTransfer expiring, then finds it locally and asks Biobak questions about intended door/shadow behavior (fade-in).

zeina.summary: Zeina is the dependency for finalizing Goomba King animations; Kaze indicates the current animation behavior likely isn’t what Zeina intended and decides to message her a list of required animations and send the newest working file.
Zeina is implicitly responsible for animation intent/quality checks (eyes closed, kick/angry animations, general correctness), while Kaze handles exporting and integration via Fast64/Blender.

findings.summary: Lilaa is referenced as having seen the reworked level and is used as a point of comparison for judging whether the rework was “worth it.”
Lilaa helps troubleshoot a Blender/texture-layer issue after Kaze renames layers and the materials turn purple; Kaze asks her directly for help.

Kyle participates in discussion about YouTube titles/thumbnails vs. content quality and audience targeting; Kaze agrees that titles/thumbnails get the click but content must deliver watch time and recommendations.
Nova suggests a humorous/feature idea (unclear specifics in transcript), prompting Kaze to note he can think of a low-cost way to implement it when inactive.
ZeroVolt is credited in passing in a music/context aside (“this was music zero volt”), implying ongoing community involvement around music/assets, though not developed further in this stream.

memorable_quotes.speaker: Kaze
memorable_quotes.quote: If you want to be successful making video games you need to be mentally unwell.
memorable_quotes.context: Kaze’s philosophy on the persistence required to finish a large game project despite tedious tasks, compromises, and creative blocks.

memorable_quotes.speaker: Kaze
memorable_quotes.quote: It has to be like, here is a UI that is a natural evolution of Mario 64’s UI.
memorable_quotes.context: UI redesign discussion: he rejects arbitrary ‘3D world UI’ proposals and emphasizes respectful evolution of the original game’s language.

memorable_quotes.speaker: Kaze
memorable_quotes.quote: A lot of people don’t seem to understand that… I’m making my own game.
memorable_quotes.context: Explaining why he’s rewriting/decompiling SM64 and planning a main-channel video to correct audience misconceptions.

key_stories.title: Goomba boss fight rework driven by Biobak feedback
key_stories.summary: Kaze dedicates the stream to implementing Biobak’s requested changes to the Goomba boss encounter. The revised design shifts agency toward the player aiming a boulder that follows Mario, while the boss chooses positions, requiring new AI, tuning, and presentation polish.
key_stories.challenge: The existing fight behavior and enemy interactions (spiky Goombas, boulder behavior, boss positioning) were not matching the desired design and contained visible glitches and unreliable interactions.
key_stories.process: Kaze debugs spiky Goomba teleporting/disappearing, fixes biased random position generation, adjusts boulder travel and inversion issues, and modifies Goomba push/approach logic. He identifies remaining needs (kick/angry animations, boss doors, better disappearance, shadow work, draw-distance tuning, collision edits).
key_stories.outcome: Core logic largely works by the end (Goombas push and return; boulder can be aimed), but remaining animation assets and boss doors are deferred; Kaze plans to message Zeina and finish later/off-stream.

key_stories.title: N64-focused visual/performance pass: mipmaps, lighting fixes, and bloom experiment
key_stories.summary: Kaze shows off recent N64-targeted improvements: mipmaps are implemented, N64 lighting works again after a macro bug, and an area crash is fixed. He also experiments with a bloom-like effect but treats it as a performance-budgeted feature for selective areas only.
key_stories.challenge: Maintaining N64 compatibility and stability while improving visuals; evaluating expensive post effects within strict RDP/frame budgets.
key_stories.process: Implements mipmaps, fixes N64 lighting macro issue, fixes a crash, tests a bloom approach and compares cost (~7 ms RDP in an example) to where it could be safely used.
key_stories.outcome: Stability and visuals improved on N64; bloom remains an experimental/conditional feature for future themed areas (casino/space arcade) if performance allows.

key_stories.title: Explaining the project to the wider audience (and title ‘slop’ anxiety)
key_stories.summary: Kaze reacts to YouTube comments that misunderstand his work as ‘still talking about Mario 64’ rather than developing a new game. He outlines a plan for upcoming videos and debates punchy ‘slop-adjacent’ titles versus accurate framing, crediting Biobak with strong title ideas.
key_stories.challenge: Audience expectation mismatch and discoverability: viewers assume he’s only making SM64 videos; clickbait titles might increase reach but risk attracting the wrong audience or harming credibility.
key_stories.process: He drafts a video roadmap (BLJ video, then a ‘secret reason’/project explanation video, then Missing Link updates via Zell) and iterates on title concepts while discussing algorithm dynamics (thumbnail/title + watch time).
key_stories.outcome: He commits to a clearer messaging video to explain RTYI/rewriting SM64 as game creation, and he adopts/seriously considers Biobak’s stronger title framing.
key_stories.key_quote: The secret reason I’ve been rewriting Mario 64.

key_stories.title: Animation pipeline friction: Fast64 exports and missing animations
key_stories.summary: While integrating the Goomba King, Kaze discovers animation inconsistencies (wrong model/pose, eyes state, bubble timing), missing exports (walk forward), looping issues, and a specific animation index linked to a crash. He decides to offload remaining animation creation to Zeina.
key_stories.challenge: Keeping the boss model/animations consistent and crash-free in the N64 pipeline while coordinating who owns which part of the asset work.
key_stories.process: He audits animation slots, fixes or re-exports problematic sequences, notes Fast64’s animation-table behavior, and establishes a list of missing/needed animations to send to Zeina (kick, angry, etc.).
key_stories.outcome: Most animations are integrated; remaining animation work is explicitly queued for Zeina, and Kaze proceeds with gameplay/door logic instead of finishing animation work on-stream.

key_stories.title: Blender material/layer bug interrupts boss-door shadow setup
key_stories.summary: While setting up boss door assets (including a shadow that should fade in), Kaze triggers a Blender/Fast64-related material issue: after renaming layers/tabs, textures turn purple and Ctrl-Z doesn’t fix it. He asks Lilaa for help, then moves on with a pragmatic workaround.
key_stories.challenge: Tooling instability: a confusing material/layer state change breaks expected rendering and slows asset integration.
key_stories.process: Kaze attempts to revert, investigates texture validity, asks Lilaa for troubleshooting, then proceeds with implementing a fade-in shadow behavior anyway.
key_stories.outcome: Shadow fade behavior is accepted as ‘perfect,’ but the underlying Blender/material oddity remains unclear; Kaze ends the stream feeling exhausted and defers completion.

open_questions.topic: Final intended Goomba boss fight design spec
open_questions.context: Kaze implements a revised loop (boss picks spot; boulder follows Mario; Goombas push boulder; boss doors open when angry), but several polish items and edge cases remain (inverted directions, disappearing, timing, difficulty).
questions: What is the complete intended phase structure of the Goomba King fight (phases, triggers, fail states)?
How did Biobak’s feedback change the fight compared to the previous iteration, and why were those changes important for ‘RTYI’ identity?
What difficulty targets are you aiming for (first-time player success rate, time-to-learn, damage tuning)?
What is the role of the ‘boss doors’ in gameplay (gating, pacing, spectacle), and how are they triggered exactly?

open_questions.context: Kaze says only the kick animation and possibly an angry animation remain, and he plans to send Zeina the newest file and an animation list.
questions: What specific animations does Zeina own for this boss (kick, angry, idle variants, eyes states), and what reference material is she using (Yoshi’s Island tone, SM64 style, something else)?
How do Kaze and Zeina iterate on animation feedback—does Kaze request changes after integrating into engine, or does Zeina preview in Blender first?
What caused the earlier mismatch (e.g., ‘wrong Goomba King,’ sideways pose) and how do you prevent that pipeline confusion?

open_questions.topic: N64 bloom effect: decision criteria and implementation plan
open_questions.context: Kaze experiments with bloom and references an example costing ~7 ms of RDP time; he suggests using it only in sub-areas with performance headroom (casino/space arcade).
questions: What bloom approach did you prototype (downsample/blur strategy, thresholding), and what were the concrete performance numbers on hardware?
What are your rules for allowing expensive post effects in RTYI (specific FPS thresholds, area size limits, camera constraints)?
Which future levels/themes are candidates for bloom, and what mood/story purpose would it serve?

open_questions.topic: N64 compatibility fixes: mipmaps and lighting macro bug
open_questions.context: Kaze implemented mipmaps and fixed N64 lighting after a ‘stupid macro bug,’ plus a crash in the Goomba area.
questions: What were the exact visual artifacts mipmaps solved in RTYI, and what tradeoffs did they introduce (memory, texture authoring constraints)?
What was the macro bug that broke lighting on N64, and how did you detect/confirm the fix on real hardware?
What was the area crash cause, and what does it reveal about the fragility of the current engine/toolchain?

open_questions.context: Kaze mentions an area might be close to 60 FPS but hasn’t measured, and he makes collision simplifications for tiny FPS gains.
questions: What is the project’s hard performance target (30/60 on hardware), and where do you allow dips?
How do you profile on N64 (tools, repeatable test scenes, frame-time budgets for RSP/RDP)?
How often do micro-optimizations (collision trimming) meaningfully add up across a full course?

open_questions.topic: Collision and enemy navigation design rules
open_questions.context: He edits geometry/collision to stop enemies getting stuck and to prevent spike Goombas jumping over a fence, noting some areas are ‘inaccessible anyway.’
questions: Do you maintain a set of ‘AI-safe’ collision guidelines when building levels (slope limits, step height, fence rules)?
How do you decide when to change enemy logic versus changing level geometry?
What tooling do you use to visualize/debug enemy navigation failures?

open_questions.context: Kaze wants a UI that’s a natural evolution of SM64’s UI, not a disconnected “3D world UI.”
questions: What specific UI elements are you willing to change (health, coin/star counters, prompts), and what must remain recognizable?
How do you balance nostalgia/readability with new mechanics that might require new HUD elements?
Do you have UI mockups or prototypes, and who will implement the final UI art?

open_questions.topic: Communicating ‘this is a new game’ to the Mario 64 audience
open_questions.context: Kaze describes persistent viewer misunderstanding and plans an explanatory main-channel video; he debates high-performing titles that could be perceived as ‘slop.’
questions: When did you realize a large portion of the audience didn’t understand RTYI is a full new game, and how did that affect dev/marketing choices?
How do you decide what progress to show publicly without spoiling levels or attracting unhelpful feedback?
What’s the long-term plan for messaging RTYI’s identity: ROM hack vs. original game, and how respectful to SM64 it should feel?

open_questions.topic: Nintendo takedown risk and contingency planning
open_questions.context: Kaze briefly mentions writing someone on Twitter about Nintendo takedowns and widespread worry, but doesn’t detail a plan.
questions: What specific takedown events or policy changes triggered this concern at the time of the stream?
What is your mitigation strategy (mirrors, messaging, release timing, legal consultation, distribution model)?
How does takedown fear influence what you show on streams/videos?

open_questions.topic: Zell’s role and the Missing Link update plan
open_questions.context: Kaze says a Missing Link ‘version updates’ video is being worked on by Zell and Kaze will pay him to do it, but details are sparse.
questions: Who is Zell in your production pipeline (editor, developer, producer), and how did that collaboration start?
What are the Missing Link updates, and how do they relate to RTYI (shared tech, audience bridging, funding attention)?
Why outsource/pay for this particular video, and what does it free Kaze up to do on the dev side?
